results.title: The Third Planet
results.creator_credit: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Miracle Planet”.
Volume 1 of “The Miracle Planet” series which examines craters and meteorites and the clues they provide for understanding the origin of the Earth and its atmosphere. It also shows the ways meteorite impacts continue to affect the planet.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)

results.title: Patterns in the Air
results.creator_credit: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “The Miracle Planet”.
Volume 4 “Patterns in the air” examines the atmosphere that envelops the Earth. This surprisingly thin cocoon supports all life on Earth. The distance between the tops of trees to the fringes of outer space is only a few miles, yet that blanket of water and gases has made Earth unique.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)

results.title: Succession from sand dune to forest
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Explains that succession is the process by which a given area changes slowly and continuously until it finally becomes a stable community. Shows one of the earliest and most thoroughly studied examples of this process on the shore of Lake Michigan

results.title: The Home Planet
results.creator_credit: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Miracle Planet”.
The home planet is the final volume of “The miracle planet” series and looks at some of the major questions confronting the human race. With our population growing, the supply of our resources dwindling, our atmosphere threatened, and the spectre of malnutrition and starvation haunting more and more of the Earth’s population, what are the prospects for the planet continuing to support human life?
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barry Stoner and KCTS (Television station : Seattle, Wash.)

results.title: Mountains of memories : Digital Storytelling project
results.brief_description: Four stories from people with a deep connection to the Victorian Alpine Country. From different backgrounds, they share their experiences of working, living and travelling to the Alpine country, the stories of ancestors who have mined and lived in the region and how the Alpine country has left an indeliable impression on their lives.
results.description: Four stories from people with a deep connection to the Victorian Alpine Country. results.title: Ecology of a hot spring: life at high temperatures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Uses the hot springs of Yellowstone National Park as a laboratory for the study of organisms that can survive the effects of high temperatures. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Plankton and the open sea
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Pictures typical forms of plankton and demonstrates the importance of minute plankton organisms to marine food chains. Also shows how plankton is studied. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The High arctic biome
results.creator_credit: Hugh O'Connor, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Biology program; unit 1. Ecology”.
Describes the constant struggle of plants and animals for survival in the harsh environment of the high arctic biome. Photographed on the arctic coastal lands of Canada. Suitable for upper secondary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hugh O’Connor, Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and National Film Board of Canada
